title: As a future teacher, how are you going to teach science in this new normal? - Quora

response.answer_text: Vanessa, I’m a science teacher educator. My course this year is entirely on-line, for the first time every in my long career. Remember, this pandemic will not last—life will return to some familiar patterns. In the meanwhile, my advice to those teaching students science is to: Get the students to do as many of the experiments as possible at home. LOTS of labs in secondary school science adapt easily to using home equipment. For example, you don’t need graduated cylinders, etc—measuring cups and spoons will do.For those labs that should not be done at home (or even the science classroom), such as the reaction of the alkali metals with water or the reaction of sodium with chlorine gas, refer students to YouTube videos.Have regular contact with the entire class to give the students a sense of structure. PowerPoints work well here, but don’t overdo the content.Adopt a “flipped classroom” approach. I’m going to try that myself this term and we will see how it goes, but the flipped classroom approach really lines up well with an on-line course.Remember for lots of students, science “just doesn’t make sense” so provide opportunities for on-line tutoring.Don’t worry—this too shall pass. All the best, David
